Notas importantes: - ✅ Variables con prefijo NEXT_PUBLIC_* (disponibles en cliente) - ✅ DIFY_APP_CODE es el código del WebApp (≠ app_id) - ✅ URL interna del LoadBalancer de Dify

docs.title: 2. Componente React (DifyChatButton.tsx)
docs.text:
Ubicación: apps/control-center-ui/app/components/DifyChatButton.tsx

'use client';

import { useState } from 'react';

export default function DifyChatButton() {
  const [isOpen, setIsOpen] = useState(false);

  const DIFY_URL = process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_DIFY_URL || 'http://10.0.2.91';
  const DIFY_APP_CODE = process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_DIFY_APP_CODE || '7C9Ppi4gev9j1h7p';
  const chatbotUrl = `${DIFY_URL}/chatbot/${DIFY_APP_CODE}`;

  const handleOpenChat = () => {
    window.open(chatbotUrl, 'dify-chat', 'width=400,height=600,resizable=yes');
  };

  const handleToggleIframe = () => {
    setIsOpen(!isOpen);
  };

  return (
    <>
      {/* Botón flotante */}
      <button
        onClick={handleToggleIframe}
        className="fixed bottom-6 right-6 w-14 h-14 bg-gradient-to-r from-green-500 to-emerald-600 text-white rounded-full shadow-lg hover:shadow-2xl transition-all z-50 flex items-center justify-center hover:scale-110"
        aria-label="Abrir chatbot"
      >
        💬
      </button>

      {/* Iframe del chatbot (cuando está abierto) */}
      {isOpen && (
        <div className="fixed bottom-24 right-6 w-96 h-[600px] bg-white rounded-2xl shadow-2xl z-50 flex flex-col overflow-hidden border-2 border-green-200">
          {/* Header */}
          <div className="bg-gradient-to-r from-green-500 to-emerald-600 text-white p-4 flex justify-between items-center">
            <div className="flex items-center gap-2">
              <span className="text-xl">🤖</span>
              <span className="font-semibold">Nirvana Assistant</span>
            </div>
            <div className="flex gap-2">
              <button
                onClick={handleOpenChat}
                className="hover:bg-white/20 p-2 rounded transition-all"
                title="Abrir en nueva ventana"
              >
                ↗️
              </button>
              <button
                onClick={handleToggleIframe}
                className="hover:bg-white/20 p-2 rounded transition-all"
                title="Cerrar"
              >
                ✖️
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>

          {/* Iframe content */}
          <iframe
            src={chatbotUrl}
            className="flex-1 w-full border-0"
            title="Dify Chatbot"
            allow="microphone"
          />
        </div>
      )}
    </>
  );
}

Características: - ✅ Botón flotante con emoji 💬 - ✅ Gradient verde corporativo (green-500 → emerald-600) - ✅ Dos modos: Iframe embebido o nueva ventana - ✅ Header personalizado con nombre "Nirvana Assistant" - ✅ Botones de cerrar y expandir - ✅ Responsive y animaciones suaves

docs.title: Problema 1: El botón flotante no aparece
docs.text:
Síntomas: No se ve el botón verde en la esquina inferior derecha.

Solución: 1. Verificar que DifyChatButton.tsx existe en apps/control-center-ui/app/components/ 2. Verificar que layout.tsx importa y renderiza <DifyChatButton /> 3. Hard refresh del navegador (Ctrl + Shift + R) 4. Revisar consola del navegador para errores de React

docs.title: Problema 2: El iframe no carga el chatbot
docs.text:

NEXT_PUBLIC_DIFY_URL=http://10.0.2.91

2. Reiniciar el servidor Next.js (las variables de entorno solo se cargan al inicio) 3. Verificar acceso directo a: http://10.0.2.91/chatbot/7C9Ppi4gev9j1h7p

docs.title: Problema 3: Error "App with code ... not found"
docs.text:
Síntomas: El WebApp muestra error de aplicación no encontrada.

Causa: El WebApp está deshabilitado en la base de datos.

Solución: 

# Conectar a PostgreSQL y habilitar WebApp
kubectl run psql-enable-site --rm -i --restart=Never --image=postgres:15 -n dify \
  --env="PGPASSWORD=:hAqXVV>wqjB*:)SJhPZD25n" -- \
  psql -h dify-postgres-9107e36a.postgres.database.azure.com -p 5432 -U difyadmin -d dify \
  -c "UPDATE apps SET enable_site = true WHERE id = '3b4e8375-30db-4351-afca-78b3e98ca0d3';"

docs.title: Problema 4: El chat no responde
docs.text:
Síntomas: El chat se abre pero no responde a mensajes.

Solución: 1. Verificar que Dify API está funcionando: 

curl http://10.0.2.91/health
2. Verificar logs de Dify: 
kubectl logs -n dify -l app.kubernetes.io/component=api --tail=50
3. Verificar configuración de Azure OpenAI en Dify UI

docs.title: Problema 5: CORS errors en la consola
docs.text:
Síntomas: Errores de CORS al cargar el iframe.

Causa: Dify no está configurado para permitir embeddings.

Solución: Verificar que Dify permite iframe embeddings (configuración por defecto en Dify 1.9.2).

docs.title: ¿Por qué no usamos embed.min.js oficial?
docs.text:
Intentamos primero la integración con el widget oficial de Dify:

<Script src="http://10.0.2.91/embed.min.js" />

Problemas encontrados: - ❌ Error 401: Autenticación fallida incluso con token correcto - ❌ Error 400: Endpoint /api/login/status no existe o requiere autenticación diferente - ❌ Complejidad innecesaria para nuestro caso de uso

Solución final (iframe): - ✅ Más simple y estable - ✅ No requiere autenticación (WebApp público) - ✅ Mayor control sobre UX - ✅ Compatible con Next.js Server Components

docs.title: Diferencia entre App ID y WebApp Code

App ID (UUID):           3b4e8375-30db-4351-afca-78b3e98ca0d3

SELECT code FROM sites WHERE app_id = '3b4e8375-30db-4351-afca-78b3e98ca0d3';

docs.title: 🤖 Dify Dataset Configuration - Nirvana Knowledge Portal
Overview
docs.text: This guide walks you through creating and configuring a Dify Knowledge Dataset for the Nirvana Knowledge Portal.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• VPN connected (OpenVPN)
  • Database nirvana_knowledge created
  • Access to Dify UI: http://10.0.2.91

docs.title: Step 1: Access Dify Interface
docs.text:
1. Connect to VPN: 

    sudo openvpn --config /mnt/c/PROYECTS/dify-azure-private-deployment/vpn-config/mi-laptop.ovpn

  2. Open Dify in browser:

  3. URL: http://10.0.2.91
  4. Login with your Dify credentials

docs.title: Step 2: Create New Knowledge Base
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Knowledge:
  2. Click on "Knowledge" in the left sidebar

  3. Click "+ Create Knowledge" button

  4. Configure Basic Settings: 

    Name: Nirvana Knowledge Portal
Description: Technical documentation, ADRs, code examples, and runbooks for DXC Cloud Mind - Nirvana PoC
Icon: 🧠 (brain emoji)

  5. Select Knowledge Type:

  6. Choose: "External Knowledge Base" (we'll use our custom pgvector database)
  7. OR choose: "Internal" if you want Dify to manage everything

docs.title: Embedding Model Configuration
docs.text:
1. Select Embedding Provider:
  2. Provider: Azure OpenAI
  3. Model: text-embedding-3-large

  4. Dimensions: 3072

  5. Embedding Settings: 

    Batch Size: 100
Max Tokens per Chunk: 800
Overlap Tokens: 100

docs.title: Retrieval Configuration
docs.text:
1. Retrieval Method:
  2. Method: Vector Search + Keyword

  3. This combines semantic search (vector) with traditional keyword search

  4. Retrieval Parameters: 

    Top K: 5
Score Threshold: 0.50
Max Tokens: 4000
Rerank: Enabled
Rerank Model: Cohere Rerank (or compatible)

Note: Score threshold of 0.50 is recommended based on production testing. Typical similarity scores range 0.50-0.65 for relevant matches with: - text-embedding-3-large (3072 dimensions) - Multilingual queries (Spanish/English) - Semantic (not exact) matching

  1. Chunking Strategy: 
    Automatic Chunking: Disabled (we do custom chunking)
Chunk Size: 800 tokens
Chunk Overlap: 100 tokens
Separator: "\n\n" (double newline)

docs.title: Step 4: Connect to Vector Database (pgvector)
docs.text:
If using External Knowledge Base:

  1. Database Connection: 

    Database Type: PostgreSQL (pgvector)
Host: dify-postgres-9107e36a.postgres.database.azure.com
Port: 5432
Database: nirvana_knowledge
User: difyadmin
Password: [from secret]
SSL Mode: require

  2. Table Mapping: 

    Embeddings Table: knowledge_chunks
Vector Column: embedding
Content Column: content
Metadata Columns:
  - source_type
  - category
  - file_path
  - repository
  - tags
  - language

docs.title: Step 5: Configure Indexing Rules
docs.text:
1. File Type Filters: 

    Allowed Extensions:
  - .md (Markdown)
  - .py (Python)
  - .ts (TypeScript)
  - .tsx (TypeScript React)
  - .yaml (YAML)
  - .yml (YAML)
  - .json (JSON)
  - .sh (Shell scripts)

Excluded Patterns:
  - node_modules/**
  - .git/**
  - dist/**
  - build/**
  - *.min.js
  - *.map

  2. Metadata Extraction: 

    Extract from Git:
  - Commit SHA
  - Author
  - Commit Date
  - Branch

Extract from File:
  - File Path
  - File Size
  - Last Modified
  - Language (from extension)

docs.title: Step 6: Create Test Documents
docs.text:
Upload a few test documents to verify the setup:

  1. Test Document 1 - Create test-architecture.md: 

    # Architecture Overview

This is a test document to verify the Knowledge Portal setup.

## Components
- AKS Cluster: dify-aks
- PostgreSQL: dify-postgres-9107e36a
- Vector Extension: pgvector

## Tags
#architecture #azure #kubernetes

  2. Upload to Dify:

  3. Click "Add Document"
  4. Upload test-architecture.md

  5. Wait for processing

  6. Verify Indexing:

  7. Check that document appears in the list
  8. Status should be "Completed"
  9. Click on document to see chunks

docs.title: Step 7: Test Retrieval
docs.text:
1. Open Knowledge Base Testing:
  2. Click on the knowledge base

  3. Go to "Test" tab

  4. Test Queries: 

    Query 1: "What AKS cluster is used?"
Expected: Should return info about dify-aks

Query 2: "How is the vector database configured?"
Expected: Should return info about pgvector

Query 3: "What is the PostgreSQL host?"
Expected: Should return dify-postgres-9107e36a.postgres.database.azure.com

  5. Check Results:

  6. Verify that relevant chunks are returned
  7. Check similarity scores (should be > 0.70)
  8. Verify metadata is present

docs.title: Step 8: Create RAG Application
docs.text:
Now create a chat application that uses this knowledge base:

  1. Create New App:
  2. Click "Studio" → "+ Create Application"
  3. Name: Nirvana Knowledge Assistant

  4. Type: Chat App

  5. Configure App: 

    Model: gpt-4o-mini (Azure OpenAI)
Temperature: 0.3
Max Tokens: 2000
Top P: 0.9

  6. Add Knowledge Base:

  7. In "Context" section
  8. Click "+ Add Knowledge"
  9. Select "Nirvana Knowledge Portal"

  10. Retrieval Mode: Multi-path Retrieval

  11. System Prompt: 

    You are an expert technical assistant for the DXC Cloud Mind - Nirvana project.

Your role is to help engineers with:
- Architecture decisions and ADRs
- Code examples and best practices
- Troubleshooting issues
- Infrastructure questions
- Azure and Kubernetes guidance

RULES:
1. Answer based ONLY on the provided documentation context
2. If information is not in the context, say "I don't have that information in the knowledge base"
3. Cite sources by mentioning the document name
4. Be concise but thorough
5. Use code examples when appropriate
6. Format responses in Markdown

CONTEXT:
The following documentation chunks are relevant to the user's question:
{context}

USER QUESTION:
{query}

  12. Test the App:

  13. Click "Debug and Preview"
  14. Try the same test queries
  15. Verify responses are accurate and cite sources

docs.title: Step 9: Configure API Access
docs.text:
1. Generate API Key:
  2. Go to App Settings
  3. Navigate to "API Keys"
  4. Click "+ Create API Key"
  5. Name: Knowledge Portal API

  6. Save the key securely

  7. Test API: 

    curl -X POST "http://10.0.2.91/v1/chat-messages" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "inputs": {},
    "query": "What is the AKS cluster name?",
    "user": "test-user",
    "response_mode": "blocking"
  }'

docs.title: Step 10: Enable WebApp (Optional)
docs.text:
If you want a public-facing chat interface:

  1. Enable Site:
  2. Go to App Settings

  3. Toggle "Enable Site" to ON

  4. Get WebApp Code:

  5. Copy the WebApp code (e.g., abc123def456)

  6. URL will be: http://10.0.2.91/chatbot/abc123def456

  7. Update Knowledge Portal Config: 

    // apps/control-center-ui/.env.local
NEXT_PUBLIC_KNOWLEDGE_WEBAPP_CODE=abc123def456

docs.title: Verification Checklist
docs.text:
• Knowledge base created and configured
  • Embedding model set to text-embedding-3-large
  • Retrieval settings configured (top_k=5, threshold=0.70)
  • Vector database connected (pgvector)
  • Test documents uploaded and indexed
  • Test queries return relevant results
  • RAG application created and tested
  • API key generated and tested
  • WebApp enabled (if needed)

docs.title: Issue 1: "Connection to vector database failed"
docs.text:
Solution: - Verify VPN is connected - Check PostgreSQL credentials - Test connection manually: 

psql -h dify-postgres-9107e36a.postgres.database.azure.com \
     -U difyadmin -d nirvana_knowledge

docs.title: Issue 2: "Embedding generation failed"
docs.text: Solution: - Verify Azure OpenAI is configured in Dify - Check API key is valid - Verify model text-embedding-3-large is deployed

docs.title: Issue 3: "No results returned for queries"
docs.text:
Solution: - Lower score threshold (try 0.60) - Increase top_k (try 10) - Check that documents were actually indexed - Verify vector column has data: 

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM knowledge_chunks WHERE embedding IS NOT NULL;

docs.title: Issue 4: "Chunks are too large/small"
docs.text:
Solution: - Adjust chunk size in settings - We use custom chunking, so this shouldn't affect our pipeline - Verify our chunks are ~800 tokens: 

SELECT AVG(LENGTH(content)) FROM knowledge_chunks;

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Configure GitHub Actions to sync documentation automatically
  2. Implement FastAPI backend for custom queries
  3. Integrate with Next.js UI
  4. Build VS Code extension

docs.title: Initial Indexing Guide
docs.text: Para realizar la indexación inicial de la documentación en el Knowledge Portal, puedes usar uno de estos métodos:

docs.title: Método 1: GitHub Actions Workflow (Recomendado)
docs.text: El workflow ya está configurado y tiene acceso al repositorio y a todos los secrets necesarios.

docs.title: Trigger manual con todos los archivos:
docs.text:
gh workflow run sync-knowledge-base.yml \
  --repo AlbertoLacambra/dify-azure-private-deployment \
  --field force_reindex=true

docs.title: Verificar ejecución:
docs.text:
# Listar ejecuciones
gh run list --repo AlbertoLacambra/dify-azure-private-deployment --workflow=sync-knowledge-base.yml

# Ver logs de la última ejecución
gh run view --repo AlbertoLacambra/dify-azure-private-deployment --log

docs.title: Método 2: Script Local (Requiere VPN + Conectividad a PostgreSQL)
docs.text:
Si tienes conectividad directa a PostgreSQL:

# Configurar variables de entorno
export AZURE_OPENAI_API_KEY="<YOUR_AZURE_OPENAI_KEY>"
export AZURE_OPENAI_ENDPOINT="https://alberto-resource.cognitiveservices.azure.com/openai"
export AZURE_OPENAI_DEPLOYMENT="text-embedding-3-large"
export POSTGRES_HOST="dify-postgres-9107e36a.postgres.database.azure.com"
export POSTGRES_USER="difyadmin"
export POSTGRES_PASSWORD="<YOUR_POSTGRES_PASSWORD>"
export POSTGRES_DB="nirvana_knowledge"

# Ejecutar indexación
./scripts/knowledge/index-initial-docs.sh

docs.title: Método 3: Commit y Push (Automático)
docs.text:
El workflow se ejecuta automáticamente en cada push a master que modifique archivos en: - docs/** - apps/** - kubernetes/** - scripts/**

Simplemente haz commit y push de cualquier cambio en esos directorios.

docs.title: Verificación Post-Indexación
docs.text:
Una vez completada la indexación, verifica con:

# Método 1: Si tienes acceso a PostgreSQL
python3 scripts/knowledge/verify-knowledge-sync.py

# Método 2: Usando Kubernetes Job
kubectl apply -f kubernetes/knowledge-portal/verify-sync-job.yaml
kubectl logs -n cloudmind job/verify-knowledge-sync --follow

docs.title: Archivos a Indexar Inicialmente
docs.text:
Ver lista en: scripts/knowledge/initial-docs.txt

Total: ~20 archivos de documentación incluyendo: - Arquitectura - Guías de usuario - Referencias técnicas - Casos de uso

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Guía para migración futura de Terraform standalone a Terragrunt para gestión multi-subscription.

docs.title: Beneficios
docs.text:
• DRY principle: No repetir código backend
  • Multi-env: Gestión simplificada de múltiples entornos
  • Dependencies: Gestión automática de dependencias entre módulos
  • Remote state: Configuración centralizada

docs.title: Estructura Propuesta
docs.text:
terragrunt/
├── terragrunt.hcl              # Root configuration
├── environments/
│   ├── hub/
│   │   ├── terragrunt.hcl
│   │   ├── acr/
│   │   │   └── terragrunt.hcl
│   │   └── aks/
│   │       └── terragrunt.hcl
│   ├── spoke-prod/
│   │   └── terragrunt.hcl
│   └── spoke-dev/
│       └── terragrunt.hcl
└── modules/
    ├── container-registry/
    └── aks-namespaces/

docs.title: Phase 1: Setup Terragrunt
docs.text:
# Install Terragrunt
brew install terragrunt  # macOS
# or
wget https://github.com/gruntwork-io/terragrunt/releases/download/v0.50.0/terragrunt_linux_amd64

docs.title: Phase 2: Convert Configuration
docs.text:
Root terragrunt.hcl:

remote_state {
  backend = "azurerm"
  config = {
    resource_group_name  = "terraform-state-rg"
    storage_account_name = "tfstate${get_env("ENV", "hub")}"
    container_name       = "tfstate"
    key                  = "${path_relative_to_include()}/terraform.tfstate"
  }
}

docs.title: Phase 3: Migrate Modules
docs.text:
Environment terragrunt.hcl:

include "root" {
  path = find_in_parent_folders()
}

terraform {
  source = "../../../modules//container-registry"
}

inputs = {
  location = "westeurope"
  environment = "production"
}

docs.title: Phase 4: Test Migration
docs.text:
cd environments/hub/acr
terragrunt plan
terragrunt apply

docs.title: Estado Actual
docs.text:
Prioridad: LOW (Single environment actualmente)

Trigger: Cuando se añadan spoke subscriptions

#!/bin/bash
# diagnose-teams.sh

echo "1. Testing webhook URL..."
RESPONSE=$(curl -s -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code}" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"text":"test"}' \

docs.title: 1. container-registry
docs.text:
Path: terraform/modules/container-registry

Purpose: Azure Container Registry con role assignments

Inputs:

Variable Type Description Default location string Azure region Required resource_group_name string RG name Required aks_kubelet_identity_object_id string AKS identity for AcrPull Required enable_diagnostic_setting bool Enable diagnostics false log_analytics_workspace_id string Workspace ID null tags map(string) Resource tags {}

Outputs:

Output Description acr_id ACR resource ID acr_login_server ACR login server URL acr_name ACR name

Usage:

module "acr" {
  source = "../../modules/container-registry"

  location            = "westeurope"
  resource_group_name = azurerm_resource_group.acr.name
  aks_kubelet_identity_object_id = data.azurerm_kubernetes_cluster.dify.kubelet_identity[0].object_id

  tags = {
    Environment = "Production"
    Project     = "CloudMind"
  }
}

docs.title: 2. aks-namespaces
docs.text:
Path: terraform/modules/aks-namespaces

Purpose: Kubernetes namespace con resource quotas

Inputs:

Variable Type Description Default namespace_name string K8s namespace name Required cpu_requests string CPU requests quota "4" memory_requests string Memory requests quota "8Gi" cpu_limits string CPU limits quota "6" memory_limits string Memory limits quota "12Gi" pods string Max pods "30"

Outputs:

Output Description namespace_name Created namespace name resource_quota_name Created quota name

Usage:

module "cloudmind_namespace" {
  source = "../../modules/aks-namespaces"

  namespace_name    = "cloudmind"
  cpu_requests      = "4"
  memory_requests   = "8Gi"
  cpu_limits        = "6"
  memory_limits     = "12Gi"
  pods              = "30"
}

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
module-name/
├── main.tf           # Resources
├── variables.tf      # Input variables
├── outputs.tf        # Output values
├── versions.tf       # Provider versions
└── README.md         # Documentation

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Versioning: Use semantic versioning
  2. Documentation: Auto-generate with terraform-docs
  3. Testing: Test modules before use
  4. Variables: Use sensible defaults
  5. Outputs: Expose useful values

docs.title: Example Module
docs.text:
# variables.tf
variable "name" {
  description = "Resource name"
  type        = string
}

# main.tf
resource "azurerm_resource_group" "this" {
  name     = var.name
  location = "westeurope"
}

# outputs.tf
output "id" {
  description = "Resource group ID"
  value       = azurerm_resource_group.this.id
}

docs.title: 🎯 Problema
docs.text: Los desarrolladores pierden 2-3 días configurando un nuevo proyecto desde cero:

docs.title: Pain Points Actuales
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ Setup inicial lento (4-8 horas)
  2. Crear estructura de carpetas
  3. Configurar dependencias
  4. Setup de entorno virtual

  5. Configurar linters, formatters

  6. 📝 Boilerplate repetitivo (8-12 horas)

  7. Models, schemas, routes
  8. Authentication/Authorization
  9. Database connection
  10. Error handling

  11. Logging

  12. 🧪 Testing desde cero (4-6 horas)

  13. Setup pytest
  14. Fixtures
  15. Tests unitarios base

  16. Tests de integración

  17. 🚀 CI/CD configuration (4-8 horas)

  18. GitHub Actions workflows
  19. Docker multi-stage builds
  20. Kubernetes manifests

  21. Helm charts (opcional)

  22. 📚 Documentación inicial (2-4 horas)

  23. README
  24. API docs (OpenAPI/Swagger)
  25. Contributing guidelines

Total: 22-38 horas (2.75-4.75 días) por proyecto

docs.title: Impacto Organizacional
docs.text:
• 30 developers x 4 proyectos nuevos/año = 120 proyectos
  • 120 x 30 horas promedio = 3,600 horas/año desperdiciadas
  • 3,600 horas x €30/h = €108,000/año en coste de oportunidad

docs.title: 💡 Solución
docs.text:
Vibe Coding Studio permite a developers describir su proyecto en lenguaje natural y la IA genera:

✅ Código completo con best practices ✅ Tests automáticos (unitarios + integración) ✅ CI/CD pre-configurado ✅ Documentación completa ✅ Deploy-ready en minutos

docs.title: Ejemplo de Input
docs.text:
👤 Developer:

"Crear una API REST en Python con FastAPI para gestionar una biblioteca digital.

Funcionalidades:
- Gestión de libros (CRUD)
- Gestión de usuarios con autenticación JWT
- Sistema de préstamos con fechas
- Búsqueda avanzada por autor, título, ISBN

Tecnologías:
- FastAPI con Python 3.11+
- PostgreSQL como base de datos
- SQLAlchemy ORM
- Alembic para migraciones
- Redis para caching
- Pytest para testing
- Deploy en Kubernetes (AKS)

Requisitos:
- API RESTful con OpenAPI docs
- Autenticación JWT
- Rate limiting
- Logging estructurado
- Health checks
- Prometheus metrics
- CI/CD con GitHub Actions
"

docs.title: Flujo de Generación de Código
docs.text:
# Pseudocódigo del proceso

def generate_project(user_description: str) -> Project:
    # 1. Parse requirements
    requirements = parse_natural_language(user_description)
    """
    requirements = {
        'type': 'api',
        'framework': 'fastapi',
        'language': 'python',
        'features': ['crud', 'auth', 'search'],
        'database': 'postgresql',
        'cache': 'redis',
        'deployment': 'kubernetes'
    }
    """

    # 2. Select template
    template = select_template(requirements)
    # template = 'python-fastapi-postgresql'

    # 3. Generate project structure
    structure = generate_structure(template, requirements)
    """
    structure = {
        'app/main.py': {...},
        'app/models/': {...},
        'tests/': {...},
        ...
    }
    """

    # 4. Generate code for each file
    for file_path, spec in structure.items():
        code = llm.generate_code(
            template=spec.template,
            context=requirements,
            best_practices=get_best_practices(file_path)
        )
        structure[file_path]['content'] = code

    # 5. Generate tests
    tests = generate_tests(structure, requirements)

    # 6. Generate CI/CD
    cicd = generate_cicd_config(requirements)

    # 7. Generate documentation
    docs = generate_documentation(structure, requirements)

    # 8. Validate everything
    validation_results = validate_project(
        structure, tests, cicd, docs
    )

    if not validation_results.is_valid:
        fix_issues(structure, validation_results.issues)

    # 9. Return complete project
    return Project(
        structure=structure,
        tests=tests,
        cicd=cicd,
        docs=docs,
        metadata={
            'lines_of_code': count_loc(structure),
            'test_coverage': calculate_coverage(tests),
            'security_score': calculate_security_score(structure)
        }
    )
